text: And if your eye causes you to stumble, gouge it out and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life with one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into the fire of hell.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘See that you do not despise one of these little ones. For I tell you that their angels in heaven always see the face of my Father in heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘What do you think? If a man owns a hundred sheep, and one of them wanders away, will he not leave the ninety-nine on the hills and go to look for the one that wandered off?
speaker: Narrator

text: And if he finds it, truly I tell you, he is happier about that one sheep than about the ninety-nine that did not wander off.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way your Father in heaven is not willing that any of these little ones should perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If your brother or sister sins, go and point out their fault, just between the two of you. If they listen to you, you have won them over.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they will not listen, take one or two others along, so that “every matter may be established by the testimony of two or three witnesses.”
speaker: Narrator

text: If they still refuse to listen, tell it to the church; and if they refuse to listen even to the church, treat them as you would a pagan or a tax collector.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Truly I tell you, whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will be loosed in heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Again, truly I tell you that if two of you on earth agree about anything they ask for, it will be done for them by my Father in heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: For where two or three gather in my name, there am I with them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Peter came to Jesus and asked, ‘Lord, how many times shall I forgive my brother or sister who sins against me? Up to seven times?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, ‘I tell you, not seven times, but seventy-seven times.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Therefore, the kingdom of heaven is like a king who wanted to settle accounts with his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he began the settlement, a man who owed him ten thousand bags of gold was brought to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since he was not able to pay, the master ordered that he and his wife and his children and all that he had be sold to repay the debt.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘At this the servant fell on his knees before him. “Be patient with me,” he begged, “and I will pay back everything.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant’s master took pity on him, cancelled the debt and let him go.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But when that servant went out, he found one of his fellow servants who owed him a hundred silver coins. He grabbed him and began to choke him. “Pay back what you owe me!” he demanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘His fellow servant fell to his knees and begged him, “Be patient with me, and I will pay it back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But he refused. Instead, he went off and had the man thrown into prison until he could pay the debt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the other servants saw what had happened, they were outraged and went and told their master everything that had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then the master called the servant in. “You wicked servant,” he said, “I cancelled all that debt of yours because you begged me to.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shouldn’t you have had mercy on your fellow servant just as I had on you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: In anger his master handed him over to the jailers to be tortured, until he should pay back all he owed.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘This is how my heavenly Father will treat each of you unless you forgive your brother or sister from your heart.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus had finished saying these things, he left Galilee and went into the region of Judea to the other side of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Large crowds followed him, and he healed them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some Pharisees came to him to test him. They asked, ‘Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife for any and every reason?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Haven’t you read,’ he replied, ‘that at the beginning the Creator “made them male and female,”
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “For this reason a man will leave his father and mother and be united to his wife, and the two will become one flesh”?
speaker: Narrator

text: So they are no longer two, but one flesh. Therefore what God has joined together, let no one separate.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Why then,’ they asked, ‘did Moses command that a man give his wife a certificate of divorce and send her away?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, ‘Moses permitted you to divorce your wives because your hearts were hard. But it was not this way from the beginning.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you that anyone who divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, and marries another woman commits adultery.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The disciples said to him, ‘If this is the situation between a husband and wife, it is better not to marry.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, ‘Not everyone can accept this word, but only those to whom it has been given.
speaker: Narrator

text: For there are eunuchs who were born that way, and there are eunuchs who have been made eunuchs by others – and there are those who choose to live like eunuchs for the sake of the kingdom of heaven. The one who can accept this should accept it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then people brought little children to Jesus for him to place his hands on them and pray for them. But the disciples rebuked them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, ‘Let the little children come to me, and do not hinder them, for the kingdom of heaven belongs to such as these.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had placed his hands on them, he went on from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then a man came up to Jesus and asked, ‘Teacher, what good thing must I do to get eternal life?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Why do you ask me about what is good?’ Jesus replied. ‘There is only One who is good. If you want to enter life, keep the commandments.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Which ones?’ he enquired.
Jesus replied, ‘“You shall not murder, you shall not commit adultery, you shall not steal, you shall not give false testimony,
speaker: Narrator

text: honour your father and mother,” and “love your neighbour as yourself.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘All these I have kept,’ the young man said. ‘What do I still lack?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, ‘If you want to be perfect, go, sell your possessions and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When the young man heard this, he went away sad, because he had great wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to his disciples, ‘Truly I tell you, it is hard for someone who is rich to enter the kingdom of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again I tell you, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for someone who is rich to enter the kingdom of God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When the disciples heard this, they were greatly astonished and asked, ‘Who then can be saved?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus looked at them and said, ‘With man this is impossible, but with God all things are possible.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter answered him, ‘We have left everything to follow you! What then will there be for us?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to them, ‘Truly I tell you, at the renewal of all things, when the Son of Man sits on his glorious throne, you who have followed me will also sit on twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And everyone who has left houses or brothers or sisters or father or mother or wife or children or fields for my sake will receive a hundred times as much and will inherit eternal life.
speaker: Narrator

text: But many who are first will be last, and many who are last will be first.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘For the kingdom of heaven is like a landowner who went out early in the morning to hire workers for his vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: He agreed to pay them a denarius for the day and sent them into his vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘About nine in the morning he went out and saw others standing in the market-place doing nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, “You also go and work in my vineyard, and I will pay you whatever is right.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they went.
‘He went out again about noon and about three in the afternoon and did the same thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: About five in the afternoon he went out and found still others standing around. He asked them, “Why have you been standing here all day long doing nothing?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘“Because no one has hired us,” they answered.
‘He said to them, “You also go and work in my vineyard.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When evening came, the owner of the vineyard said to his foreman, “Call the workers and pay them their wages, beginning with the last ones hired and going on to the first.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The workers who were hired about five in the afternoon came and each received a denarius.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when those came who were hired first, they expected to receive more. But each one of them also received a denarius.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they received it, they began to grumble against the landowner.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These who were hired last worked only one hour,” they said, “and you have made them equal to us who have borne the burden of the work and the heat of the day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But he answered one of them, “I am not being unfair to you, friend. Didn’t you agree to work for a denarius?
speaker: Narrator

text: Take your pay and go. I want to give the one who was hired last the same as I gave you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t I have the right to do what I want with my own money? Or are you envious because I am generous?”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘So the last will be first, and the first will be last.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jesus was going up to Jerusalem. On the way, he took the Twelve aside and said to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘We are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be delivered over to the chief priests and the teachers of the law. They will condemn him to death
speaker: Narrator

text: and will hand him over to the Gentiles to be mocked and flogged and crucified. On the third day he will be raised to life!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the mother of Zebedee’s sons came to Jesus with her sons and, kneeling down, asked a favour of him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘What is it you want?’ he asked.
She said, ‘Grant that one of these two sons of mine may sit at your right and the other at your left in your kingdom.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘You don’t know what you are asking,’ Jesus said to them. ‘Can you drink the cup I am going to drink?’
‘We can,’ they answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to them, ‘You will indeed drink from my cup, but to sit at my right or left is not for me to grant. These places belong to those for whom they have been prepared by my Father.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When the ten heard about this, they were indignant with the two brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus called them together and said, ‘You know that the rulers of the Gentiles lord it over them, and their high officials exercise authority over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not so with you. Instead, whoever wants to become great among you must be your servant,
speaker: Narrator

text: and whoever wants to be first must be your slave –
speaker: Narrator

text: just as the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many.’
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jesus and his disciples were leaving Jericho, a large crowd followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two blind men were sitting by the roadside, and when they heard that Jesus was passing by, they shouted, ‘Lord, Son of David, have mercy on us!’
speaker: Narrator

text: The crowd rebuked them and told them to be quiet, but they shouted all the louder, ‘Lord, Son of David, have mercy on us!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus stopped and called them. ‘What do you want me to do for you?’ he asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Lord,’ they answered, ‘we want our sight.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus had compassion on them and touched their eyes. Immediately they received their sight and followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they approached Jerusalem and came to Bethphage on the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two disciples,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying to them, ‘Go to the village ahead of you, and at once you will find a donkey tied there, with her colt by her. Untie them and bring them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone says anything to you, say that the Lord needs them, and he will send them right away.’
speaker: Narrator

text: This took place to fulfil what was spoken through the prophet:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Say to Daughter Zion,
    “See, your king comes to you,
gentle and riding on a donkey,
    and on a colt, the foal of a donkey.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The disciples went and did as Jesus had instructed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought the donkey and the colt and placed their cloaks on them for Jesus to sit on.
speaker: Narrator

text: A very large crowd spread their cloaks on the road, while others cut branches from the trees and spread them on the road.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The crowds that went ahead of him and those that followed shouted,
‘Hosanna to the Son of David!’
‘Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord!’
‘Hosanna in the highest heaven!’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus entered Jerusalem, the whole city was stirred and asked, ‘Who is this?’
speaker: Narrator

text: The crowds answered, ‘This is Jesus, the prophet from Nazareth in Galilee.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus entered the temple courts and drove out all who were buying and selling there. He overturned the tables of the money-changers and the benches of those selling doves.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘It is written,’ he said to them, ‘“My house will be called a house of prayer,” but you are making it “a den of robbers.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The blind and the lame came to him at the temple, and he healed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the chief priests and the teachers of the law saw the wonderful things he did and the children shouting in the temple courts, ‘Hosanna to the Son of David,’ they were indignant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Do you hear what these children are saying?’ they asked him.
‘Yes,’ replied Jesus, ‘have you never read,
‘“From the lips of children and infants
    you, Lord, have called forth your praise”?’
speaker: Narrator

text: And he left them and went out of the city to Bethany, where he spent the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early in the morning, as Jesus was on his way back to the city, he was hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seeing a fig-tree by the road, he went up to it but found nothing on it except leaves. Then he said to it, ‘May you never bear fruit again!’ Immediately the tree withered.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the disciples saw this, they were amazed. ‘How did the fig-tree wither so quickly?’ they asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, ‘Truly I tell you, if you have faith and do not doubt, not only can you do what was done to the fig-tree, but also you can say to this mountain, “Go, throw yourself into the sea,” and it will be done.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you believe, you will receive whatever you ask for in prayer.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus entered the temple courts, and, while he was teaching, the chief priests and the elders of the people came to him. ‘By what authority are you doing these things?’ they asked. ‘And who gave you this authority?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, ‘I will also ask you one question. If you answer me, I will tell you by what authority I am doing these things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
John’s baptism – where did it come from? Was it from heaven, or of human origin?’
They discussed it among themselves and said, ‘If we say, “From heaven”, he will ask, “Then why didn’t you believe him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But if we say, “Of human origin”– we are afraid of the people, for they all hold that John was a prophet.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they answered Jesus, ‘We don’t know.’
Then he said, ‘Neither will I tell you by what authority I am doing these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘What do you think? There was a man who had two sons. He went to the first and said, “Son, go and work today in the vineyard.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“I will not,” he answered, but later he changed his mind and went.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then the father went to the other son and said the same thing. He answered, “I will, sir,” but he did not go.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Which of the two did what his father wanted?’
‘The first,’ they answered.
Jesus said to them, ‘Truly I tell you, the tax collectors and the prostitutes are entering the kingdom of God ahead of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For John came to you to show you the way of righteousness, and you did not believe him, but the tax collectors and the prostitutes did. And even after you saw this, you did not repent and believe him.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Listen to another parable: there was a landowner who planted a vineyard. He put a wall round it, dug a winepress in it and built a watchtower. Then he rented the vineyard to some farmers and moved to another place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the harvest time approached, he sent his servants to the tenants to collect his fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The tenants seized his servants; they beat one, killed another, and stoned a third.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he sent other servants to them, more than the first time, and the tenants treated them in the same way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Last of all, he sent his son to them. “They will respect my son,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But when the tenants saw the son, they said to each other, “This is the heir. Come, let’s kill him and take his inheritance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took him and threw him out of the vineyard and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Therefore, when the owner of the vineyard comes, what will he do to those tenants?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘He will bring those wretches to a wretched end,’ they replied, ‘and he will rent the vineyard to other tenants, who will give him his share of the crop at harvest time.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jesus said to them, ‘Have you never read in the Scriptures:
‘“The stone the builders rejected
    has become the cornerstone;
the Lord has done this,
    and it is marvellous in our eyes”?
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Therefore I tell you that the kingdom of God will be taken away from you and given to a people who will produce its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who falls on this stone will be broken to pieces; anyone on whom it falls will be crushed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When the chief priests and the Pharisees heard Jesus’ parables, they knew he was talking about them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They looked for a way to arrest him, but they were afraid of the crowd because the people held that he was a prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus spoke to them again in parables, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The kingdom of heaven is like a king who prepared a wedding banquet for his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent his servants to those who had been invited to the banquet to tell them to come, but they refused to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then he sent some more servants and said, “Tell those who have been invited that I have prepared my dinner: my oxen and fattened cattle have been slaughtered, and everything is ready. Come to the wedding banquet.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But they paid no attention and went off – one to his field, another to his business.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest seized his servants, ill-treated them and killed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king was enraged. He sent his army and destroyed those murderers and burned their city.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then he said to his servants, “The wedding banquet is ready, but those I invited did not deserve to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: So go to the street corners and invite to the banquet anyone you find.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the servants went out into the streets and gathered all the people they could find, the bad as well as the good, and the wedding hall was filled with guests.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But when the king came in to see the guests, he noticed a man there who was not wearing wedding clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked, “How did you get in here without wedding clothes, friend?” The man was speechless.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then the king told the attendants, “Tie him hand and foot, and throw him outside, into the darkness, where there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘For many are invited, but few are chosen.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Pharisees went out and laid plans to trap him in his words.
speaker: Narrator

text: They sent their disciples to him along with the Herodians. ‘Teacher,’ they said, ‘we know that you are a man of integrity and that you teach the way of God in accordance with the truth. You aren’t swayed by others, because you pay no attention to who they are.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell us then, what is your opinion? Is it right to pay the poll-tax to Caesar or not?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus, knowing their evil intent, said, ‘You hypocrites, why are you trying to trap me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Show me the coin used for paying the tax.’ They brought him a denarius,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he asked them, ‘Whose image is this? And whose inscription?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Caesar’s,’ they replied.
Then he said to them, ‘So give back to Caesar what is Caesar’s, and to God what is God’s.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard this, they were amazed. So they left him and went away.
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day the Sadducees, who say there is no resurrection, came to him with a question.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Teacher,’ they said, ‘Moses told us that if a man dies without having children, his brother must marry the widow and raise up offspring for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there were seven brothers among us. The first one married and died, and since he had no children, he left his wife to his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same thing happened to the second and third brother, right on down to the seventh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, the woman died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, at the resurrection, whose wife will she be of the seven, since all of them were married to her?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, ‘You are in error because you do not know the Scriptures or the power of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the resurrection people will neither marry nor be given in marriage; they will be like the angels in heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: But about the resurrection of the dead – have you not read what God said to you,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob”? He is not the God of the dead but of the living.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When the crowds heard this, they were astonished at his teaching.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hearing that Jesus had silenced the Sadducees, the Pharisees got together.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of them, an expert in the law, tested him with this question:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Teacher, which is the greatest commandment in the Law?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied: ‘“Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your mind.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the first and greatest commandment.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the second is like it: “Love your neighbour as yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Law and the Prophets hang on these two commandments.’
speaker: Narrator

text: While the Pharisees were gathered together, Jesus asked them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘What do you think about the Messiah? Whose son is he?’
‘The son of David,’ they replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, ‘How is it then that David, speaking by the Spirit, calls him “Lord”? For he says,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘“The Lord said to my Lord:
    ‘Sit at my right hand
until I put your enemies
    under your feet.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: If then David calls him “Lord”, how can he be his son?’
speaker: Narrator

text: No one could say a word in reply, and from that day on no one dared to ask him any more questions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to the crowds and to his disciples:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The teachers of the law and the Pharisees sit in Moses’ seat.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you must be careful to do everything they tell you. But do not do what they do, for they do not practise what they preach.
speaker: Narrator

text: They tie up heavy, cumbersome loads and put them on other people’s shoulders, but they themselves are not willing to lift a finger to move them.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Everything they do is done for people to see: they make their phylacteries wide and the tassels on their garments long;
speaker: Narrator

text: they love the place of honour at banquets and the most important seats in the synagogues;
speaker: Narrator

text: they love to be greeted with respect in the market-places and to be called “Rabbi” by others.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But you are not to be called “Rabbi”, for you have one Teacher, and you are all brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: And do not call anyone on earth “father”, for you have one Father, and he is in heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nor are you to be called instructors, for you have one Instructor, the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The greatest among you will be your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You shut the door of the kingdom of heaven in people’s faces. You yourselves do not enter, nor will you let those enter who are trying to.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You travel over land and sea to win a single convert, and when you have succeeded, you make them twice as much a child of hell as you are.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Woe to you, blind guides! You say, “If anyone swears by the temple, it means nothing; but anyone who swears by the gold of the temple is bound by that oath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: You blind fools! Which is greater: the gold, or the temple that makes the gold sacred?
speaker: Narrator

text: You also say, “If anyone swears by the altar, it means nothing; but anyone who swears by the gift on the altar is bound by that oath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: You blind men! Which is greater: the gift, or the altar that makes the gift sacred?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, anyone who swears by the altar swears by it and by everything on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And anyone who swears by the temple swears by it and by the one who dwells in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And anyone who swears by heaven swears by God’s throne and by the one who sits on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You give a tenth of your spices – mint, dill and cumin. But you have neglected the more important matters of the law – justice, mercy and faithfulness. You should have practised the latter, without neglecting the former.
speaker: Narrator

text: You blind guides! You strain out a gnat but swallow a camel.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You clean the outside of the cup and dish, but inside they are full of greed and self-indulgence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Blind Pharisee! First clean the inside of the cup and dish, and then the outside also will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You are like whitewashed tombs, which look beautiful on the outside but on the inside are full of the bones of the dead and everything unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, on the outside you appear to people as righteous but on the inside you are full of hypocrisy and wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You build tombs for the prophets and decorate the graves of the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you say, “If we had lived in the days of our ancestors, we would not have taken part with them in shedding the blood of the prophets.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So you testify against yourselves that you are the descendants of those who murdered the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go ahead, then, and complete what your ancestors started!
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You snakes! You brood of vipers! How will you escape being condemned to hell?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I am sending you prophets and sages and teachers. Some of them you will kill and crucify; others you will flog in your synagogues and pursue from town to town.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so upon you will come all the righteous blood that has been shed on earth, from the blood of righteous Abel to the blood of Zechariah son of Berekiah, whom you murdered between the temple and the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Truly I tell you, all this will come upon this generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Jerusalem, Jerusalem, you who kill the prophets and stone those sent to you, how often I have longed to gather your children together, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, and you were not willing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, your house is left to you desolate.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I tell you, you will not see me again until you say, “Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus left the temple and was walking away when his disciples came up to him to call his attention to its buildings.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Do you see all these things?’ he asked. ‘Truly I tell you, not one stone here will be left on another; every one will be thrown down.’
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jesus was sitting on the Mount of Olives, the disciples came to him privately. ‘Tell us,’ they said, ‘when will this happen, and what will be the sign of your coming and of the end of the age?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered: ‘Watch out that no one deceives you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For many will come in my name, claiming, “I am the Messiah,” and will deceive many.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will hear of wars and rumours of wars, but see to it that you are not alarmed. Such things must happen, but the end is still to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom. There will be famines and earthquakes in various places.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these are the beginning of birth-pains.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then you will be handed over to be persecuted and put to death, and you will be hated by all nations because of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time many will turn away from the faith and will betray and hate each other,
speaker: Narrator

text: and many false prophets will appear and deceive many people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of the increase of wickedness, the love of most will grow cold,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the one who stands firm to the end will be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this gospel of the kingdom will be preached in the whole world as a testimony to all nations, and then the end will come.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘So when you see standing in the holy place “the abomination that causes desolation,” spoken of through the prophet Daniel – let the reader understand –
speaker: Narrator

text: then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let no one on the housetop go down to take anything out of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let no one in the field go back to get their cloak.
speaker: Narrator

text: How dreadful it will be in those days for pregnant women and nursing mothers!
speaker: Narrator

text: Pray that your flight will not take place in winter or on the Sabbath.
speaker: Narrator

text: For then there will be great distress, unequalled from the beginning of the world until now – and never to be equalled again.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If those days had not been cut short, no one would survive, but for the sake of the elect those days will be shortened.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time if anyone says to you, “Look, here is the Messiah!” or, “There he is!” do not believe it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For false messiahs and false prophets will appear and perform great signs and wonders to deceive, if possible, even the elect.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I have told you in advance.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘So if anyone tells you, “There he is, out in the desert,” do not go out; or, “Here he is, in the inner rooms,” do not believe it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as lightning that comes from the east is visible even in the west, so will be the coming of the Son of Man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever there is a carcass, there the vultures will gather.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Immediately after the distress of those days
‘“the sun will be darkened,
    and the moon will not give its light;
the stars will fall from the sky,
    and the heavenly bodies will be shaken.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then will appear the sign of the Son of Man in heaven. And then all the peoples of the earth will mourn when they see the Son of Man coming on the clouds of heaven, with power and great glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he will send his angels with a loud trumpet call, and they will gather his elect from the four winds, from one end of the heavens to the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Now learn this lesson from the fig-tree: as soon as its twigs become tender and its leaves come out, you know that summer is near.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even so, when you see all these things, you know that it is near, right at the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: Truly I tell you, this generation will certainly not pass away until all these things have happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will never pass away.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But about that day or hour no one knows, not even the angels in heaven, nor the Son, but only the Father.
speaker: Narrator

text: As it was in the days of Noah, so it will be at the coming of the Son of Man.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in the days before the flood, people were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, up to the day Noah entered the ark;
speaker: Narrator

text: and they knew nothing about what would happen until the flood came and took them all away. That is how it will be at the coming of the Son of Man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two men will be in the field; one will be taken and the other left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two women will be grinding with a hand mill; one will be taken and the other left.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Therefore keep watch, because you do not know on what day your Lord will come.
speaker: Narrator

text: But understand this: if the owner of the house had known at what time of night the thief was coming, he would have kept watch and would not have let his house be broken into.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you also must be ready, because the Son of Man will come at an hour when you do not expect him.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Who then is the faithful and wise servant, whom the master has put in charge of the servants in his household to give them their food at the proper time?
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be good for that servant whose master finds him doing so when he returns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Truly I tell you, he will put him in charge of all his possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: But suppose that servant is wicked and says to himself, “My master is staying away a long time,”
speaker: Narrator

text: and he then begins to beat his fellow servants and to eat and drink with drunkards.
speaker: Narrator

text: The master of that servant will come on a day when he does not expect him and at an hour he is not aware of.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will cut him to pieces and assign him a place with the hypocrites, where there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘At that time the kingdom of heaven will be like ten virgins who took their lamps and went out to meet the bridegroom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five of them were foolish and five were wise.
speaker: Narrator

text: The foolish ones took their lamps but did not take any oil with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wise ones, however, took oil in jars along with their lamps.
speaker: Narrator

text: The bridegroom was a long time in coming, and they all became drowsy and fell asleep.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘At midnight the cry rang out: “Here’s the bridegroom! Come out to meet him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then all the virgins woke up and trimmed their lamps.
speaker: Narrator

text: The foolish ones said to the wise, “Give us some of your oil; our lamps are going out.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“No,” they replied, “there may not be enough for both us and you. Instead, go to those who sell oil and buy some for yourselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But while they were on their way to buy the oil, the bridegroom arrived. The virgins who were ready went in with him to the wedding banquet. And the door was shut.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Later the others also came. “Lord, Lord,” they said, “open the door for us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But he replied, “Truly I tell you, I don’t know you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Therefore keep watch, because you do not know the day or the hour.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Again, it will be like a man going on a journey, who called his servants and entrusted his wealth to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: To one he gave five bags of gold, to another two bags, and to another one bag, each according to his ability. Then he went on his journey.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who had received five bags of gold went at once and put his money to work and gained five bags more.
speaker: Narrator

text: So also, the one with two bags of gold gained two more.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man who had received one bag went off, dug a hole in the ground and hid his master’s money.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘After a long time the master of those servants returned and settled accounts with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who had received five bags of gold brought the other five. “Master,” he said, “you entrusted me with five bags of gold. See, I have gained five more.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘His master replied, “Well done, good and faithful servant! You have been faithful with a few things; I will put you in charge of many things. Come and share your master’s happiness!”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The man with two bags of gold also came. “Master,” he said, “you entrusted me with two bags of gold: see, I have gained two more.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘His master replied, “Well done, good and faithful servant! You have been faithful with a few things; I will put you in charge of many things. Come and share your master’s happiness!”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then the man who had received one bag of gold came. “Master,” he said, “I knew that you are a hard man, harvesting where you have not sown and gathering where you have not scattered seed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I was afraid and went out and hid your gold in the ground. See, here is what belongs to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘His master replied, “You wicked, lazy servant! So you knew that I harvest where I have not sown and gather where I have not scattered seed?
speaker: Narrator

text: Well then, you should have put my money on deposit with the bankers, so that when I returned I would have received it back with interest.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“So take the bag of gold from him and give it to the one who has ten bags.
speaker: Narrator

text: For whoever has will be given more, and they will have an abundance. Whoever does not have, even what they have will be taken from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And throw that worthless servant outside, into the darkness, where there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When the Son of Man comes in his glory, and all the angels with him, he will sit on his glorious throne.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the nations will be gathered before him, and he will separate the people one from another as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will put the sheep on his right and the goats on his left.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then the King will say to those on his right, “Come, you who are blessed by my Father; take your inheritance, the kingdom prepared for you since the creation of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I was hungry and you gave me something to eat, I was thirsty and you gave me something to drink, I was a stranger and you invited me in,
speaker: Narrator

text: I needed clothes and you clothed me, I was ill and you looked after me, I was in prison and you came to visit me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then the righteous will answer him, “Lord, when did we see you hungry and feed you, or thirsty and give you something to drink?
speaker: Narrator

text: When did we see you a stranger and invite you in, or needing clothes and clothe you?
speaker: Narrator

text: When did we see you ill or in prison and go to visit you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The King will reply, “Truly I tell you, whatever you did for one of the least of these brothers and sisters of mine, you did for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then he will say to those on his left, “Depart from me, you who are cursed, into the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his angels.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I was hungry and you gave me nothing to eat, I was thirsty and you gave me nothing to drink,
speaker: Narrator

text: I was a stranger and you did not invite me in, I needed clothes and you did not clothe me, I was ill and in prison and you did not look after me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘They also will answer, “Lord, when did we see you hungry or thirsty or a stranger or needing clothes or ill or in prison, and did not help you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘He will reply, “Truly I tell you, whatever you did not do for one of the least of these, you did not do for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then they will go away to eternal punishment, but the righteous to eternal life.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus had finished saying all these things, he said to his disciples,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘As you know, the Passover is two days away – and the Son of Man will be handed over to be crucified.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the chief priests and the elders of the people assembled in the palace of the high priest, whose name was Caiaphas,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they schemed to arrest Jesus secretly and kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But not during the festival,’ they said, ‘or there may be a riot among the people.’
speaker: Narrator

text: While Jesus was in Bethany in the home of Simon the Leper,
speaker: Narrator

text: a woman came to him with an alabaster jar of very expensive perfume, which she poured on his head as he was reclining at the table.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the disciples saw this, they were indignant. ‘Why this waste?’ they asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘This perfume could have been sold at a high price and the money given to the poor.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Aware of this, Jesus said to them, ‘Why are you bothering this woman? She has done a beautiful thing to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poor you will always have with you, but you will not always have me.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she poured this perfume on my body, she did it to prepare me for burial.
speaker: Narrator

text: Truly I tell you, wherever this gospel is preached throughout the world, what she has done will also be told, in memory of her.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the Twelve – the one called Judas Iscariot – went to the chief priests
speaker: Narrator

text: and asked, ‘What are you willing to give me if I deliver him over to you?’ So they counted out for him thirty pieces of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: From then on Judas watched for an opportunity to hand him over.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the Festival of Unleavened Bread, the disciples came to Jesus and asked, ‘Where do you want us to make preparations for you to eat the Passover?’
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, ‘Go into the city to a certain man and tell him, “The Teacher says: my appointed time is near. I am going to celebrate the Passover with my disciples at your house.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the disciples did as Jesus had directed them and prepared the Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: When evening came, Jesus was reclining at the table with the Twelve.
speaker: Narrator

text: And while they were eating, he said, ‘Truly I tell you, one of you will betray me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: They were very sad and began to say to him one after the other, ‘Surely you don’t mean me, Lord?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, ‘The one who has dipped his hand into the bowl with me will betray me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Son of Man will go just as it is written about him. But woe to that man who betrays the Son of Man! It would be better for him if he had not been born.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Judas, the one who would betray him, said, ‘Surely you don’t mean me, Rabbi?’
Jesus answered, ‘You have said so.’
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were eating, Jesus took bread, and when he had given thanks, he broke it and gave it to his disciples, saying, ‘Take and eat; this is my body.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took a cup, and when he had given thanks, he gave it to them, saying, ‘Drink from it, all of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is my blood of the covenant, which is poured out for many for the forgiveness of sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, I will not drink from this fruit of the vine from now on until that day when I drink it new with you in my Father’s kingdom.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had sung a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jesus told them, ‘This very night you will all fall away on account of me, for it is written:
‘“I will strike the shepherd,
    and the sheep of the flock will be scattered.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But after I have risen, I will go ahead of you into Galilee.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter replied, ‘Even if all fall away on account of you, I never will.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Truly I tell you,’ Jesus answered, ‘this very night, before the cock crows, you will disown me three times.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Peter declared, ‘Even if I have to die with you, I will never disown you.’ And all the other disciples said the same.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus went with his disciples to a place called Gethsemane, and he said to them, ‘Sit here while I go over there and pray.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He took Peter and the two sons of Zebedee along with him, and he began to be sorrowful and troubled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to them, ‘My soul is overwhelmed with sorrow to the point of death. Stay here and keep watch with me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Going a little farther, he fell with his face to the ground and prayed, ‘My Father, if it is possible, may this cup be taken from me. Yet not as I will, but as you will.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he returned to his disciples and found them sleeping. ‘Couldn’t you men keep watch with me for one hour?’ he asked Peter.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Watch and pray so that you will not fall into temptation. The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He went away a second time and prayed, ‘My Father, if it is not possible for this cup to be taken away unless I drink it, may your will be done.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came back, he again found them sleeping, because their eyes were heavy.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he left them and went away once more and prayed the third time, saying the same thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he returned to the disciples and said to them, ‘Are you still sleeping and resting? Look, the hour has come, and the Son of Man is delivered into the hands of sinners.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rise! Let us go! Here comes my betrayer!’
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, Judas, one of the Twelve, arrived. With him was a large crowd armed with swords and clubs, sent from the chief priests and the elders of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the betrayer had arranged a signal with them: ‘The one I kiss is the man; arrest him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Going at once to Jesus, Judas said, ‘Greetings, Rabbi!’ and kissed him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jesus replied, ‘Do what you came for, friend.’
Then the men stepped forward, seized Jesus and arrested him.
speaker: Narrator

text: With that, one of Jesus’ companions reached for his sword, drew it out and struck the servant of the high priest, cutting off his ear.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Put your sword back in its place,’ Jesus said to him, ‘for all who draw the sword will die by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you think I cannot call on my Father, and he will at once put at my disposal more than twelve legions of angels?
speaker: Narrator

text: But how then would the Scriptures be fulfilled that say it must happen in this way?’
speaker: Narrator

text: In that hour Jesus said to the crowd, ‘Am I leading a rebellion, that you have come out with swords and clubs to capture me? Every day I sat in the temple courts teaching, and you did not arrest me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But this has all taken place that the writings of the prophets might be fulfilled.’ Then all the disciples deserted him and fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who had arrested Jesus took him to Caiaphas the high priest, where the teachers of the law and the elders had assembled.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Peter followed him at a distance, right up to the courtyard of the high priest. He entered and sat down with the guards to see the outcome.
speaker: Narrator

text: The chief priests and the whole Sanhedrin were looking for false evidence against Jesus so that they could put him to death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But they did not find any, though many false witnesses came forward.
Finally two came forward
speaker: Narrator

text: and declared, ‘This fellow said, “I am able to destroy the temple of God and rebuild it in three days.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the high priest stood up and said to Jesus, ‘Are you not going to answer? What is this testimony that these men are bringing against you?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Jesus remained silent.
The high priest said to him, ‘I charge you under oath by the living God: Tell us if you are the Messiah, the Son of God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You have said so,’ Jesus replied. ‘But I say to all of you: from now on you will see the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of the Mighty One and coming on the clouds of heaven.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the high priest tore his clothes and said, ‘He has spoken blasphemy! Why do we need any more witnesses? Look, now you have heard the blasphemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What do you think?’
‘He is worthy of death,’ they answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they spat in his face and struck him with their fists. Others slapped him
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, ‘Prophesy to us, Messiah. Who hit you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Peter was sitting out in the courtyard, and a servant-girl came to him. ‘You also were with Jesus of Galilee,’ she said.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he denied it before them all. ‘I don’t know what you’re talking about,’ he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went out to the gateway, where another servant-girl saw him and said to the people there, ‘This fellow was with Jesus of Nazareth.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He denied it again, with an oath: ‘I don’t know the man!’
speaker: Narrator

text: After a little while, those standing there went up to Peter and said, ‘Surely you are one of them; your accent gives you away.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he began to call down curses, and he swore to them, ‘I don’t know the man!’
Immediately a cock crowed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Peter remembered the word Jesus had spoken: ‘Before the cock crows, you will disown me three times.’ And he went outside and wept bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early in the morning, all the chief priests and the elders of the people made their plans how to have Jesus executed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they bound him, led him away and handed him over to Pilate the governor.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Judas, who had betrayed him, saw that Jesus was condemned, he was seized with remorse and returned the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and the elders.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I have sinned,’ he said, ‘for I have betrayed innocent blood.’
‘What is that to us?’ they replied. ‘That’s your responsibility.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Judas threw the money into the temple and left. Then he went away and hanged himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: The chief priests picked up the coins and said, ‘It is against the law to put this into the treasury, since it is blood money.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they decided to use the money to buy the potter’s field as a burial place for foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why it has been called the Field of Blood to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then what was spoken by Jeremiah the prophet was fulfilled: ‘They took the thirty pieces of silver, the price set on him by the people of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they used them to buy the potter’s field, as the Lord commanded me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Meanwhile Jesus stood before the governor, and the governor asked him, ‘Are you the king of the Jews?’
‘You have said so,’ Jesus replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he was accused by the chief priests and the elders, he gave no answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pilate asked him, ‘Don’t you hear the testimony they are bringing against you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus made no reply, not even to a single charge – to the great amazement of the governor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it was the governor’s custom at the festival to release a prisoner chosen by the crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time they had a well-known prisoner whose name was Jesus Barabbas.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when the crowd had gathered, Pilate asked them, ‘Which one do you want me to release to you: Jesus Barabbas, or Jesus who is called the Messiah?’
speaker: Narrator

text: For he knew it was out of self-interest that they had handed Jesus over to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Pilate was sitting on the judge’s seat, his wife sent him this message: ‘Don’t have anything to do with that innocent man, for I have suffered a great deal today in a dream because of him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But the chief priests and the elders persuaded the crowd to ask for Barabbas and to have Jesus executed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Which of the two do you want me to release to you?’ asked the governor.
‘Barabbas,’ they answered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘What shall I do, then, with Jesus who is called the Messiah?’ Pilate asked.
They all answered, ‘Crucify him!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Why? What crime has he committed?’ asked Pilate.
But they shouted all the louder, ‘Crucify him!’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pilate saw that he was getting nowhere, but that instead an uproar was starting, he took water and washed his hands in front of the crowd. ‘I am innocent of this man’s blood,’ he said. ‘It is your responsibility!’
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people answered, ‘His blood is on us and on our children!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he released Barabbas to them. But he had Jesus flogged, and handed him over to be crucified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the governor’s soldiers took Jesus into the Praetorium and gathered the whole company of soldiers round him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They stripped him and put a scarlet robe on him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and then twisted together a crown of thorns and set it on his head. They put a staff in his right hand. Then they knelt in front of him and mocked him. ‘Hail, king of the Jews!’ they said.
speaker: Narrator

text: They spat on him, and took the staff and struck him on the head again and again.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had mocked him, they took off the robe and put his own clothes on him. Then they led him away to crucify him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were going out, they met a man from Cyrene, named Simon, and they forced him to carry the cross.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came to a place called Golgotha (which means ‘the place of the skull’).
speaker: Narrator

text: There they offered Jesus wine to drink, mixed with gall; but after tasting it, he refused to drink it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had crucified him, they divided up his clothes by casting lots.
speaker: Narrator

text: And sitting down, they kept watch over him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above his head they placed the written charge against him: this is jesus, the king of the jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two rebels were crucified with him, one on his right and one on his left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who passed by hurled insults at him, shaking their heads
speaker: Narrator

text: and saying, ‘You who are going to destroy the temple and build it in three days, save yourself! Come down from the cross, if you are the Son of God!’
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way the chief priests, the teachers of the law and the elders mocked him.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘He saved others,’ they said, ‘but he can’t save himself! He’s the king of Israel! Let him come down now from the cross, and we will believe in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He trusts in God. Let God rescue him now if he wants him, for he said, “I am the Son of God.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way the rebels who were crucified with him also heaped insults on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: From noon until three in the afternoon darkness came over all the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: About three in the afternoon Jesus cried out in a loud voice, ‘Eli, Eli, lema sabachthani?’ (which means ‘My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?’).
speaker: Narrator

text: When some of those standing there heard this, they said, ‘He’s calling Elijah.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Immediately one of them ran and got a sponge. He filled it with wine vinegar, put it on a staff, and offered it to Jesus to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest said, ‘Now leave him alone. Let’s see if Elijah comes to save him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And when Jesus had cried out again in a loud voice, he gave up his spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that moment the curtain of the temple was torn in two from top to bottom. The earth shook, the rocks split
speaker: Narrator

text: and the tombs broke open. The bodies of many holy people who had died were raised to life.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came out of the tombs after Jesus’ resurrection and went into the holy city and appeared to many people.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the centurion and those with him who were guarding Jesus saw the earthquake and all that had happened, they were terrified, and exclaimed, ‘Surely he was the Son of God!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Many women were there, watching from a distance. They had followed Jesus from Galilee to care for his needs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among them were Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James and Joseph, and the mother of Zebedee’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: As evening approached, there came a rich man from Arimathea, named Joseph, who had himself become a disciple of Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Going to Pilate, he asked for Jesus’ body, and Pilate ordered that it be given to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph took the body, wrapped it in a clean linen cloth,
speaker: Narrator

text: and placed it in his own new tomb that he had cut out of the rock. He rolled a big stone in front of the entrance to the tomb and went away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mary Magdalene and the other Mary were sitting there opposite the tomb.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, the one after Preparation Day, the chief priests and the Pharisees went to Pilate.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Sir,’ they said, ‘we remember that while he was still alive that deceiver said, “After three days I will rise again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So give the order for the tomb to be made secure until the third day. Otherwise, his disciples may come and steal the body and tell the people that he has been raised from the dead. This last deception will be worse than the first.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Take a guard,’ Pilate answered. ‘Go, make the tomb as secure as you know how.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went and made the tomb secure by putting a seal on the stone and posting the guard.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the Sabbath, at dawn on the first day of the week, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary went to look at the tomb.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a violent earthquake, for an angel of the Lord came down from heaven and, going to the tomb, rolled back the stone and sat on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: His appearance was like lightning, and his clothes were white as snow.
speaker: Narrator

text: The guards were so afraid of him that they shook and became like dead men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel said to the women, ‘Do not be afraid, for I know that you are looking for Jesus, who was crucified.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is not here; he has risen, just as he said. Come and see the place where he lay.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then go quickly and tell his disciples: “He has risen from the dead and is going ahead of you into Galilee. There you will see him.” Now I have told you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the women hurried away from the tomb, afraid yet filled with joy, and ran to tell his disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly Jesus met them. ‘Greetings,’ he said. They came to him, clasped his feet and worshipped him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to them, ‘Do not be afraid. Go and tell my brothers to go to Galilee; there they will see me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: While the women were on their way, some of the guards went into the city and reported to the chief priests everything that had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the chief priests had met with the elders and devised a plan, they gave the soldiers a large sum of money,
speaker: Narrator

text: telling them, ‘You are to say, “His disciples came during the night and stole him away while we were asleep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: If this report gets to the governor, we will satisfy him and keep you out of trouble.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the soldiers took the money and did as they were instructed. And this story has been widely circulated among the Jews to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the eleven disciples went to Galilee, to the mountain where Jesus had told them to go.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they saw him, they worshipped him; but some doubted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus came to them and said, ‘All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore go and make disciples of all nations, baptising them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,
speaker: Narrator

text: and teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you. And surely I am with you always, to the very end of the age.’
speaker: Narrator
